item.title: Wife Imposing Her Friends & Family At Husband's Residence Against His Will Amounts To Cruelty: Calcutta... - Live Law - Indian Legal News
item.description:
Calcutta High Court Rules Against Wife for Imposing Guests on Husband

Date: 2024-01-15 | Source: Live Law

The Calcutta High Court has ruled that a wife imposing her friends and family on her husband at his residence without his consent amounts to cruelty.

“Such imposition of friend and family of the respondent on the husband at his quarter against his will… can definitely be constituted as cruelty…”
  • The appellant-husband filed for divorce citing cruelty due to the wife's actions.
  • The court noted that the wife's behavior made life unbearable for the husband.
  • There were disputes regarding the wife's alleged false accusations against the husband.
  • The bench emphasized that the unique circumstances of the couple's case must be considered.
  • The appeal by the husband was granted, resulting in a divorce decree.

Case: Mr. Dhiraj Guin Vs. Mrs. Tanusree Majumder | Case No: F.A. No. 1 of 2022 | Citation: 2024 LiveLaw (Cal) 283

item.title: Centre scraps ‘no-detention policy’ for classes 5 and 8 students - The Hindu
item.description:
Centre scraps ‘no-detention policy’ for classes 5 and 8 students

Date: December 23, 2024 | Source: The Hindu

The Centre has announced the removal of the 'no-detention policy' for classes five and eight in schools under its jurisdiction, allowing failure for students who do not pass year-end exams. This change follows amendments to the Right to Education Act (RTE) made in 2019.

  • At least 16 States and 2 Union Territories have already abandoned the 'no-detention policy'.
  • Children who fail will receive remedial instruction and an opportunity for re-examination within two months.
  • If the re-examination is unsuccessful, the child will be held back in their current class.
  • No child will be expelled from school until completing elementary education.
  • The notification affects over 3,000 central government schools.
“During the holding back of the child, the class teacher shall guide the child as well as the parents of the child, if necessary, and provide specialised inputs after identifying the learning gaps.”

This policy marks a significant shift in educational practice aimed at accountability in foundational years.
